description:
Kockiozyma suomiensis is a species of yeast that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Finland. It belongs to the phylum Ascomycota and the class Saccharomycetes.

The key characteristics of Kockiozyma suomiensis are:

1. Cell Morphology: The cells are generally spherical to ellipsoidal in shape, measuring approximately 3-6 μm in diameter.

2. Reproduction: Kockiozyma suomiensis reproduces asexually through budding, a common mode of reproduction in yeasts.

3. Physiological Properties: This yeast species is able to assimilate and ferment a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, sucrose, and maltose. It is also able to grow at a wide range of temperatures, typically between 10-37°C.

4. Habitat and Ecology: Kockiozyma suomiensis is found in soil environments and has been isolated from samples collected in Finland. It is believed to play a role in the decomposition of organic matter in its natural habitat.

5. Taxonomic Placement: Based on phylogenetic analyses of ribosomal DNA sequences, Kockiozyma suomiensis is classified within the genus Kockiozyma, which is a member of the Saccharomycetaceae family.

This brief scientific description provides an overview of the key characteristics and taxonomic placement of the yeast species Kockiozyma suomiensis, which was first discovered in the soil of Finland.
